tn.ref: Agur ... Jakeh ... Ithiel ... Ucal
tn.text: These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Agur son of Jakeh
tn.text: This is the literal son of Jakeh, not a grandchild.

tn.ref: oracle
tn.text: a message from God

tn.ref: to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal
tn.text: "to Ithiel—that is, to Ithiel and Ucal"

tn.ref: Surely
tn.text: "Certainly" or "There is no doubt that"

tn.ref: I do not have the understanding of a human being
tn.text: The abstract noun "understanding" can be translated as a verb. AT: "I do not understand anything the way human beings are supposed to understand them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: nor do I have knowledge of the Holy One
tn.text: The abstract noun "knowledge" can be translated as a verb. AT: "nor do I really know anything about the Holy One" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Who has ... down? Who has ... hands? Who has ... cloak? Who has ... earth?
tn.text: The writer asks these questions to get the reader thinking about how much greater Yahweh is than people. AT: "No person has ever ... down. No person has ever ... hands. No person has ever ... cloak. No person has ever ... earth." or "Who has ... down? Who has ... hands? Who has ... cloak? Who has ... earth? No one has ever done any of these things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: heaven
tn.text: where God lives

tn.ref: gathered up the wind in the hollow of his hands
tn.text: The writer speaks of the wind as if it were something that a person could catch and hold in his hand. AT: "has caught the wind in his hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the hollow of his hands
tn.text: the way his hands are shaped when he is scooping up, for example, water or sand. "his cupped hands"

tn.ref: gathered up
tn.text: brought small scattered objects into a pile so they can be lifted

tn.ref: has established all the ends of the earth
tn.text: "has set up the limits for where the earth ends" or "has marked the boundaries for the ends of the earth"

tn.ref: What is his name, and what is the name of his son?
tn.text: The writer uses these questions to command the reader to give an answer. AT: "Tell me his name and the name of his son, if you know them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Surely you know!
tn.text: The writer uses irony to show that neither he nor the reader know any person who can do what the "who" in the earlier questions can do. AT: "I do not think you really know anyone who can do those things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: is tested
tn.text: Words are spoken of as if they were metals that need someone to clean the bad parts out of them. AT: "is like a precious metal from which someone has removed all the useless material" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he is a shield to those who take refuge in him
tn.text: The word "shield" is a metaphor for something that protects a person. AT: "he protects those who come and ask him to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: add to his words
tn.text: say more than he has said

tn.ref: you will be proved to be
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "he will prove that you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Put vanity and lies far away from me
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Do not allow people to speak vanity and lies to me" or 2) "Do not allow me to speak vanity and lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: vanity
tn.text: false, useless words

tn.ref: Give me neither poverty nor riches
tn.text: The writer speaks as if "poverty" and "riches"—abstract nouns that can be translated as adjectives—were physical objects that someone could give to another. AT: "Do not allow me to be either very poor or very rich" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: if I have too much, I might deny you and say
tn.text: This describes a hypothetical situation that has not happened but is possible if the writer becomes rich. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: if I become poor, I might steal and profane
tn.text: This describes a hypothetical situation that has not happened but is possible if the writer becomes poor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: I might steal and profane the name of my God
tn.text: "I might make people who know that I have stolen things think that there is no God" or "I might harm God's reputation by stealing"

tn.ref: slander
tn.text: speak falsely about another person with the desire to harm him

tn.ref: he will curse
tn.text: "the servant will curse"

tn.ref: you will be held guilty
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "people will hold you guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a generation that curses ... and does not bless ... a generation that is
tn.text: "a generation of people who curse ... and do not bless ... a generation of people that are"

tn.ref: generation
tn.text: type or class or group

tn.ref: is pure in their own eyes
tn.text: The phrase "in their own eyes" is a metonym for their opinion. AT: "believes they are pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they are not washed of their filth
tn.text: The words "washed" and "filth" speak of God forgiving people who sin as if he were washing physical filth off of the people. This can be translated in active form. AT: "God has not forgiven them of their sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: filth
tn.text: This should be translated with a polite term that includes human or animal vomit and waste.

tn.ref: eyes are raised up ... their eyelids lifted up
tn.text: These two metonyms refer to people who think that they are better than other people. Their eyes show that they are proud, and the way they look at others shows that they think they are better than those other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: There is a generation whose teeth are swords, and their jawbones are like knives, so they may devour the poor ... and the needy
tn.text: The people of the generation who speak very harmful things is spoken of as if they were wild animals with teeth and jawbones made of swords and knives, and they eat the poor and needy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: jawbones
tn.text: the bones of the face where teeth grow

tn.ref: The leech has two daughters
tn.text: This is an example of something that always wants more. AT: "Greed has two daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: leech
tn.text: a type of worm that attaches itself to the skin and sucks blood

tn.ref: "Give and give" they cry
tn.text: Another possible meaning is "and they are both named Give Me."

tn.ref: There are three things that are never satisfied, four that never say, "Enough"
tn.text: This use of the numbers "three" and "four" together here is likely a poetic device. AT: "There are four things that are never satisfied, who never say, 'Enough'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]])

tn.ref: are never satisfied
tn.text: This can be stated positively. AT: "always want more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: land that is never satisfied with water
tn.text: Land that is no longer producing food because there has been no rain is spoken of as if it were a person who does not have enough water to drink. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: scorns obedience to a mother
tn.text: The word "obedience"—an abstract noun that can be translated as a verb—is a metonym for the mother herself. AT: "considers his mother worthless and will not obey her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: his eyes ... the vultures
tn.text: The writer says that the person will die by giving two pictures of what happens to people who die away from where people live.

tn.ref: his eyes will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the ravens of the valley will peck out his eyes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: ravens
tn.text: large, shiny, black birds that eat plants and dead animals

tn.ref: he will be eaten by the vultures
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the vultures will eat him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: vultures
tn.text: any one of several large birds that eat dead animals and have small, featherless heads

tn.ref: There are three things that are ... four that I do not understand:
tn.text: The use of the numbers "three" and "four" here is likely a poetic device. AT: "There are some things that are too wonderful for me that I do not understand—four of them are:"

tn.ref: in the heart of the sea
tn.text: The "heart" refers to the middle. AT: "in the middle of the sea" or "on the open sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: she eats and she wipes her mouth
tn.text: This seems to be both a euphemism and a metaphor for committing adultery and then taking a bath. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Under three things the earth trembles, and under four it cannot bear up
tn.text: The use of the numbers "three" and "four" here is likely a poetic device. "There are some things that make the earth tremble, that it cannot endure. Four of these are:"

tn.ref: a fool when he is filled with food
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "a fool who has had enough to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a hated woman when she marries
tn.text: That is, people rightly hated her before she married; once she marries, she will be worse than she was before she married. This can be translated in active form. AT: "a woman whom good people have hated when she marries" or "an outcast woman when she marries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: takes the place of her mistress
tn.text: rules the household

tn.ref: rock badgers
tn.text: an animal with small, rounded ears, short legs, and no tail

tn.ref: lizard
tn.text: a small reptile that has four legs, a long, slender body, and a tail

tn.ref: There are three things that are ... four that are stately in how they walk
tn.text: The use of the numbers "three" and "four" here is likely a poetic device. AT: "There are some things that walk stately. Four of these are:"

tn.ref: stately
tn.text: majestic or dignified, like a king

tn.ref: strutting rooster
tn.text: an adult male chicken that walks proudly

tn.ref: churning
tn.text: strongly stirring

tn.ref: butter
tn.text: Animal milk that someone has stirred and made thick.
